Value: The following guidelines have been written taking into account the local population and resources most readily available to our organization. Whenever possible, the guidelines should be followed as written. However, patients should always be treated individually. At times it may be appropriate to stray from these guidelines: for individual patients or if specific resources are low. All cases where the guidelines are not being followed must be discussed with the Lead Medical Provider supervising the clinic. As you will discover, practicing medicine in a remote setting requires a different approach. The following guidelines were written with evidence based medicine, as well as, what is practically available and possible in our setting. Please regularly discuss patients with our Lead Medical Providers (LMPs), who have experience treating patients in our unique setting. Even relatively common conditions may be treated differently in our setting for a variety of reasons. The Lead Medical Providers are there to ensure that the treatment each of our patients receives, meets Floating Doctors' standards. Treatment plans may differ between the communities also, depending on the local resources and closest healthcare facilities.

When prescribing medications please always ensure the patient is aware of the indication, name and dosage of every medication prescribed. This will allow them to inform doctors in the future, including at other health facilities. 

This can easily be done using our Floating Doctors prescription pads (placing a script in with each bag of medications). Please keep in mind not all patients are able to read. 

In the case of an illiterate patient we have special sheets with symbols, these can be found in our provider packs. A useful resource is family members - almost always there will be a family member living in the home who is able to read and help the patient with their treatment.
                                                                                                                               
If a patient is diagnosed with a chronic condition, requiring long-term medication, please fill in a Floating Doctors card for the patient. Details of the diagnosis, medication, blood pressure and blood sugar should be documented and the card given to the patient. The cards can be modified on future visits, depending on the treatment. The cards will allow the patient, and any doctor seeing the patient, to know what we are treating them for.

For a list of all the medications we stock and prescribing information for each, please see the 'Essential Medications' section. We also have a hard copy of a 'Essential Medications' document available in clinic. This has information on all the medications we carry including the indications and dosage for each.

In clinic we also carry the British National Formulary (BNF) for adults and children. Please use the BNF for any medications queries not answered by the essential medications document. It is vital to check side effects and contraindications for all medications prescribed, particularly in children, pregnancy and breastfeeding.

In general we try and be much more conservative with prescribed treatments and only give them if absolutely necessary. 

A good example of this is the use of NSAIDs. We often have to ask volunteers to prescribe less NSAIDs because 1) we do not know if the patient has renal dysfunction 2) if the patient develops gastritis/peptic ulcer they often have very difficult access to healthcare 3) often paracetamol is sufficient and NSAID is not necessary. 

Risk benefit ratios of treatments can be different than in a provider's home country, our LMPs are there to help with prescribing decisions. Counselling patients on all possible side effects and risks is essential, as it is in all settings.

Usually present with subjective fever that can be taken as genuine in this setting.

Temperature > 38 Degrees Celsius.

Chills, rigors, sepsis.

Although the fever is frequently of viral origin, serious illness must be excluded [1]
    - Viral, bacterial, or parasitic infection
    - Pneumonia.
    - Pyelonephritis.
    - Dengue.
    - Malaria (less likely).
    - Bacterial meningitis.
    - Skin infections.
    - Malignancy.
    - Vasculitis/Autoimmune disorders.

A full assessment should be performed to identify the cause(s) of the fever. Multiple sources may be found so always do a full review. Full intake Including blood pressure, respiratory rate and heart rate. History Establish pattern and duration of fever. Review of systems. Examination Each organ system. For Children Check skin, throat and ears. Ask about GI symptoms and seizures. Urine dipstick test.

Temperature >38 degrees Celsius.

Axillary temperature underestimates core body temperature by approximately 0.5 degrees Celsius. [2] 

0.5 degrees Celsius will be added to any axillary measurements at intake.

Infants (aged 0-28 days) “All febrile neonates aged 0-28 days old should be hospitalized for presumed sepsis and treated with antibiotics pending culture results (48 hours).” [3, 4] Infants (aged 28-90 days) “All febrile infants aged 28-60 days, after having a sepsis evaluation, should be hospitalized and empirically started on intravenous antibiotics pending culture results.” [3] Infants aged 28-90 days will require a number of investigations for which hospitalization is necessary. Regardless of hospitalization outcome, these children still require follow-up every 24 hours until the fever has resolved and all cultures are negative.5 Infants (aged 3 months-3 years) “Febrile children aged 3 months to 3 years are evaluated, based on epidemiologic and focal findings revealed during the history taking and physical examination as well as whether or not these children are at low risk for serious bacterial infections [3,6]. Identification and appropriate management depends on the underlying cause. In the case of self-limiting viral infections, the only management required is advice and reassurance. If meningococcal disease is suspected, give Ceftriaxone antibiotics at the earliest opportunity. Health Education for patients and relatives Stress importance of adequate, and increased fluid intake. Do not wear too many clothes or use too many blankets. Don't wipe the sweat off immediately as this helps to cool the body. Cool baths and tepid sponging are not recommended. Antipyretic drugs Fever is the normal response of the body to infection and unless the child becomes distressed or symptomatic, fever alone should not be routinely treated.There is evidence that host defence mechanisms are enhanced by a raised temperature. Antipyretics (eg, paracetamol and ibuprofen) should therefore not be used routinely but can be of value, especially for patients with systemic disease (particularly heart failure or respiratory failure) and when fever causes acute confusion. Consider either paracetamol or ibuprofen as an option if a child appears distressed or is unwell. Pharmacological Treatment (consult BNF or BNF for children) First line: Paracetamol/Acetaminophen Second line: Ibuprofen ** Please avoid maximum dosing where appropriate. Higher dosing is not recommended in this region due to chronic dehydration and renal impairment **

Children Paracetamol/Acetaminophen: 15-20 mg/kg every 8 hrs as needed. 2nd line: Ibuprofen.* 1-2 months: 5 mg/kg every 8 hrs as needed. Over 2m: 5-10 mg/kg every 8 hrs as needed. Do not prescribe both together in children *Do not prescribe in children with rash - due to a potentially severe reaction in chicken pox Adults Paracetamol/Acetaminophen. 500-100mg every 6-8 hrs as needed. (Maximum 4g/24 hours). 2nd line: Ibuprofen 200-400 mg every 8hrs as needed.

Higher dosing of NSAIDs is not recommended in this region due to chronic dehydration and renal impairment.

Don't use Ibuprofen/aspirin in pregnant/breastfeeding women and avoid in those with peptic ulcer disease. 

Avoid Ibuprofen in children with fever and skin lesions, a rare adverse effect is worsening of skin lesions in chicken pox, which can be life-threatening. Paracetamol is the drug of choice.

In our setting one of the most common causes is dehydration [1]. Awareness of this and advice to patients to increase oral intake is therefore vital. Other causes include, but are not limited to [2]: Primary Headache Tension Migraine Cluster headache Secondary Headache The list of causes of secondary headaches is exhaustive and can be found elsewhere [1,3]. It is included but not limited to: meningitis, giant cell arteritis, sinusitis and visual problems.

History Establish patient’s normal fluid intake. Most of population drink only 1-3 glasses of water a day, often while working in the sun! A good history is critical to the diagnosis and management of headache. Particular attention must be paid to red flags [4]: Red Flags - New onset headache. - Onset after age 50 years. - Change in pattern of headache. - Worsening headache. - Acute or sudden onset. - Sudden onset during exertion/strain. - Headache worse on lying down. - In a patient with malignancy or HIV. - With fever, night sweats, weight loss. - Neurologic symptoms or signs. Exam Normal intake will be performed. Observe the patient walking and talking. Examination specific to finds on history. In case of red flags, ensure a full neurological exam is performed - including fundoscopy (to rule out papilloedema). Any questions or concerns should be raised with the supervising LMP.

Whilst access to investigations during Floating Doctors’ clinics will be somewhat limited, a simple history and examination will be ascertain the cause in most scenarios.

If any red flags or concerning features are elicited, please discuss with a Lead Medical Provider. Depending on the urgency of the situation, we can:

- Arrange an emergency hospital appointment.
- Expedite secondary care at a later date.

Check lying and standing BP (if postural symptoms). Health Education[5] -Encourage ways to increase fluid intake. (i.e., coconuts, boiled water, soups, fruit). -Explain importance of water in body. -Advise reduction of caffeinated beverages. -When urine is clear, they have drank enough water. -Enquire about other triggers - i.e. stress. Pharmacological Treatment Paracetamol 500-1000mg as needed/6-8 hrs (max 4g/24hrs). Advise only to take after they have drank 1 litre of water and if they still have the headache.

Health Education Advice about triggers (coffee/cheese/stress). Encourage a symptom diary where the patient can recognize their triggers. Acute Migraine Combination of an NSAID and an antiemetic (Ibuprofen 200 - 400 mg and Metoclopramide 10mg). Chronic Migraine Regular prophylactic medication can be considered if the patient is having more than 2 migraines per month[5,6,7]. First line: Atenolol 50 mg once a day.* Second line: Amitriptyline 12.5mg at night, Increase to 25 mg if tolerated. *Always assess for contraindications to B-blockers (asthma, heart failure, peripheral vascular disease or depression.

Other causes of headache can include: - Sinusitis. - Neck pathology. - Dental pathology. - Otitis media. - Dengue (in outbreak). - Malaria (if travel) Headache with red flags: - Space occupying lesions. - Intracranial bleeds. - Intracranial infections. - Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension. Any concerns that the headache is not just a simple tension or dehydration headache, ensure a full neurological examination including fundoscopy, in a dark room, is performed (to rule out papilloedema). Discuss cases with the floating LMP.

“Musculoskeletal pain is a well known consequence of repetitive strain, overuse, and work-related musculoskeletal disorders. 

These injuries include a variety of disorders that cause pain in bones, joints, muscles, or surrounding structures. 

The pain can be acute or chronic, focal or diffuse. Low back pain is the most common example of chronic musculoskeletal pain. 

Other examples include tendonitis and tendinosis, neuropathies, myalgia, and stress fractures [1].”

Many patients describe a long history of generalized muscular pain, worse after work.

Knee pain tends to be due to osteoarthritis.

Back pain tends to be due to poor posture, particularly when lifting heavy objects.

Shoulder and elbow pain tends to be from repetitive use (with machete or washing clothes).

History A thorough history can often elucidate a likely cause. Exclude history of direct trauma, deformity, or acute pathology (ongoing infection/ septic joint). For back pain, pay particular attention to red flag features [1,2]: Red Flags -Thoracic pain -Age of onset <20 or >50 years). -Loss of bowel or bladder control. -Weakness/numbness in limb(s). -Foot drop, disturbed gait. -Associated fever. -Saddle anaesthesia. -History of carcinoma/Tuberculosis. -Structural deformity. Examination Depending on the affected joint, it is necessary to perform a focused examination to guide management and follow up. If back pain is associated with bowel/bladder incontinence or saddle anaesthesia, a perform a digital rectal examination [3]. A full neurological exam must be performed in any patient with one or more red flags. If any alarming signs are elicited, hospital evaluation can be facilitated.

Give appropriate exercises and stretches.

Physiotherapy can be extremely beneficial.

Heat packs made with a cloth and warm water.

Advice on posture, moving, and handling techniques.

Reassurance that muscular pain is normal after hard work and it tends to subside with time. 

Advise them to return to next clinic or seek further medical advice if needed.

Weight Loss where appropriate (overweight with osteoarthritis in lower limb joints).

Paracetamol/Acetaminophen: 500-1000mg, as needed/6-8hrs. (max4g/24hrs). Also see section on joint injections if appropriate. NSAIDs not indicated, likely to cause more harm long term

Infection Risks A rare complication of joint and soft tissue injection. Hand mediated transmission is the major factor contributing to healthcare associated infection. Patient skin preparation is recommended prior to surgical procedures to reduce risk of infection. However, the absence of skin prep in clinic should not be considered an absolute contraindication to proceeding with a joint injection. Before skin preparation, the skin should be free of visible dirt. The skin preparation should be applied in concentrically enlarging circles beginning at the site of proposed injection. Alcohol based, chlorhexidine based and iodine based preparation are all suitable. Tendon Rupture There have been case reports of tendon rupture following steroid injection and ingestion. Biopsy studies have demonstrated reduced cell viability and proliferation, reduced collagen synthesis and organisation, and reduced strength as a result of tendon exposure to steroid. Therefore, it is generally best to avoid injecting steroid into the body of a tendon and, unless strongly indicated, avoid steroid injections in the vicinity of tendons at high risk of rupture due to pathology (severe tendinopathy) or anatomical location (Achilles). Osteonecrosis The risk of osteonecrosis is highest with prolonged, high doses of exogenous steroids, particularly in the presence of other risk factors. Short courses of steroids however have also been shown to increase the risk of this rare complication. Anticoagulation and joint injection If the INR <4.5 then it is generally considered safe to proceed as bleeding risks are very low. However, it is unlikely the patient will have had a recent INR so you may need to refer the patient to a specialist or for an INR or consider other treatment options. Analgesia options are often limited in these patients. The decision to do these injections in patients who are anti-coagulated requires careful consideration. The risk of halting anticoagulation is often higher than the small risk of bleeding complications, but this should always be weighed. A management plan in the event of bleeding should be discussed with the patient in advance. We have few patients receiving warfarin treatment. Steroid Type and Frequency Dexamethasone and Methylprednisolone are the two injectable steroids commonly available to Floating Doctors. There have been some suggestion of cartilage damage after steroid injection but no definitive evidence. Systematic Reviews (Stevens et al and Douglas 2012) have both concluded similarly, the frequency of injections should be guided by clinical diagnosis, treatment aims, professional opinion and experience. UpToDate provides more recent evidence (Oct 2018) advising against serial steroid injections due to concerns about potential negative effects on cartilage and disease progression; no number is cited as being safe of unsafe. Menstrual Irregularity & Cushing’s Syndrome Systemic absorption of steroid has been shown to affect the hypothalamic- pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis after steroid joint injections. This can last up to four weeks after a single injection, occasionally longer, depending on the dose and frequency of injections. This is the mechanism thought to affect menstruation. Rare cases of Cushing’s syndrome have been reported but generally using unusually high doses and frequencies. HIV patients on antiretrovirals are more susceptible to iatrogenic Cushing’s syndrome. Careful consideration should be given to this complication if multiple or repeat steroid injections are going to be undertaken. Soft tissue atrophy This is an uncommon complication of steroid injection even in superficial dermatological procedures involving steroid injection. Hyperglycaemia – Intra-articular steroid injections have been shown to elevate blood sugar in diabetic patients, starting after a few hours and lasting for several days, sometimes longer. These increases in glycaemia are statistically significant but for most patients not clinically significant. However, diabetic patients should be warned of this effect. Anaphylaxis According to the resuscitation council UK website, the time course for cardiopulmonary arrest resulting from injected medication predominantly occurs between 2- 20 minutes post injection. Patients should be asked to stay for the full 20 minutes.

A height and weight measurement for all children should be performed at all clinic visits. If either of these are abnormal, please recheck all of the following: -Child’s date of birth. -Calculated age. -Height/length measurement.* -Weight.** -Graph plotting.*** *Ideally with measure board. **Minimal clothes, weigh with mother ***Always use a ruler. If a child is premature the corrected age should charted until 2 years. (e.g. if born at 34 weeks, at 6 weeks of life their weight is plotted at day 0). If any of the above are done incorrectly then the child’s growth chart will be incorrect. Laminated Z-scores available in clinic. Use electronic scales, they must be calibrated before each clinic.

In the first week of life babies can lose up to 10% of their birth weight. This is normal. They should regain their birth weight by 2 weeks of age. 

If a baby loses more than 10% of its birth weight this is concerning and they should be referred urgently to hospital for review. Beyond 2 weeks of life, healthy babies should gain around 150-200 grams per week until age 6 months.

Concerns regarding the growth of a baby under 6 months (weight loss/failure to thrive/low z-score) should lead to an urgent referral to a paediatrician, there is more likely to be an organic cause.

Children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) can present with varying levels of oedema. The retained fluid will make the weight of the child higher and z-scores/MUACs unreliable. Oedema in a child is always a red flag Children with oedema should be immediately taken to hospital.

The underlying cause of a child’s malnutrition can be complicated and difficult to determine. Commonly it is a combination of any of the following, and they should all be considered.

Low birth weight due to intrauterine factors.

Insufficient nutrient intake; including insufficient breast feeding, late weaning and lack of household food due to
poverty.

Infections; Including diarrhoeal disease, GI worms, pneumonia.

Underlying medical conditions; Including cardiac disease, endocrine disorders, respiratory disease.

Value: All children with any degree of malnutrition should have a full assessment of the following and an LMP always needs to be involved in their care: History Weight loss. Recent or recurrent illness (fever, diarrhoea, LRTI). Review of systems. Family history/health of other children in the house. Feeding appropriately/difficulties? Breastfeeding history. Vaccination history. Home circumstances. Psychosocial wellbeing of the child. Current and recent feeding habits. Physical exam All systems. Specifically screening for heart murmurs, pneumonia, abdominal tenderness, enlarged lymph nodes, organomegaly and clubbing. Investigations Haemoglobin, blood sugar, urine dipstick, HIV test if available.

Breastfeeding counselling A huge issue in the region is that mothers exclusively breastfeed more than 6 months. WHO recommends weaning to begin at 6 months. Advise these mothers to feed the child before offering breastmilk and explain that after 6 months breast milk alone is not sufficient for her child. Some mothers also do not breastfeed their children for enough time in one go, meaning the infants do not receive the more nutrient rich milk, this should be advised against. Feeding History Ask specifically what they have for each meal, snacks and how many bottles of milk/ amount of BF they have per day. Many children have their diet bulked out with large volumes of breast milk- this has far less nutritional value than a balanced meal and can cause severe anaemia and nutritional rickets due to vitamin D and calcium deficiency. Ask about sources of protein (coconut, beans, lentils, eggs, meat, fish). Nutritional advice Ask what food is available in the house and if possible, advise a balanced diet based on what is available locally. If Diarrhoea Never stop feeding the child. Give extra food (in small and frequent meals) and extra clean water. Breastfeed more often. Inform mothers that loose stool is common with malnourished children. If this is significant diarrhea and not just loose stools, then we will treat for Giardia. Malnourished children get cold easily. Cover the child and keep it warm during night and especially during the morning hours.

The classifications that follow are for children over 6 months. Concerns regarding the growth of a baby under 6 months (weight loss/failure to thrive/low z-score) should lead to an urgent referral to a paediatrician, there is more likely to be an organic cause. There are three ways in which malnutrition can present. In clinic, we need to be able to recognise each type so that we can treat the patient effectively but also prevent any worsening of mild cases. Wasting Low weight for length/height. Stunting Low length/height for age. Underweight Low weight for age. Obesity High weight for length/height. Other: Failure to thrive This is not a classification of malnutrition but needs to be recognised and acted upon. Babies (under 6 months) who are not gaining adequate weight or children who are dropping centiles. This indicates energy requirements are exceeding energy intake and is usually due to an underlying disease process. If a clear easily treatable cause cannot be found, these children should be referred to a Paediatrician for investigation. More details about each in the following sections.

Wasting is what is sometimes referred to as acute malnutrition. Severe wasting is sometimes also known as Severe Acute malnutrition (SAM). MUAC and Z-Scores Check mid-upper-arm-circumference (MUAC) on all children 6 months to 5 years. It is a fast and reliable way of screening for and categorising wasting malnutrition. Check weight for length/height Z-Score (WfLz) for all infants under 6 months. At intake these measurements should be highlighted in the appropriate colour to bring the result to the attention of the provider. WfLz can be used in children of all ages, it is preferentially used in children under 6 months and over 5 years (because the evidence for MUAC in this group is limited). It is another way of categorising and screening for wasting. It uses length/height and weight measurements to calculate the standard deviation of weight for length/height from the mean.

Stunting is the most common malnutrition presentation we see and it is not as benign as it may seem (see complications). Stunting relates to chronic/persistent malnutrition. 

Children under 2 years have the greatest capacity for catch up growth from stunting but all children should be treated for stunting when it is recognised. Stunting is a complex, intergenerational cycle. 

Length/Height for Age Z-Score (LfAz) should be used to categorise stunting (height around or below the 3rd centile).

Please see the diagram and table above.

WfAz should be used to categorise underweight children (weight around or below the 3rd centile).

Check weight for age z-score (WfAz) if you are unsure of the categorisation from the centile (i.e. if the centile is close to the cut of you can check the weight on the chart).

Obesity is also a form of malnutrition. It is the second most common form of malnutrition we see after stunting. These patients lack micronutrients as they are not eating a balanced diet. There are many long term consequences of obesity. Classification Overweight Weight for Length/Height (WfL) z-score between +2 and +3. Obesity Weight for Length/Height (WfL) z-score +3 or over.

These patients need to be screened for underlying medical conditions. If there is a likely underlying cause they should be referred to hospital urgently. Otherwise they should be given the following treatment in clinic and reviewed next clinic or asked to take the child to the nearest Centro de Salud for monitoring on their weight in a month if appropriate. Albendazole Over 6 months and under 10 kg: 200mg. Over 6 months and Over 10kg: 400mg. Once a day on days 1 and 8. Multivitamin tablets 1 per day until next clinic. Vitamin A supplementation (under 8kg: 100,000, over 8kg 200,000) once a day on days 1, 2 and 8 (do not give if the child has received in the last 4 months). Only give if the parent has the child's vaccine card and Vitamin A has not been given. If Diarrhoea If chronic or recurrent diarrhoea give metronidazole 5 days for giardia treatment. Vaccinations If the child is not up-to-date with their vaccinations, they should be referred to the nearest clinic for the appropriate vaccinations.

Children with a likely underlying medical cause, medical complications (infections/severe dehydration/severe anaemia) or children who fail an appetite test, should be referred to the hospital urgently for assessment. In children under 6 months, the majority should be referred. Give good breastfeeding counselling. Children with an appetite, who are 6 months to 5 years of age with an MUAC of 115 – 125 or a z-score of -2/-3 and who do not have any signs of medical complications or an underlying medical condition, should be given the following treatment in clinic. Albendazole Over 6 months and under 10 kg: 200mg. Over 6 months and Over 10kg: 400mg. Once a day on days 1 and 8. Multivitamin tablets 1 per day until next clinic. Vitamin A supplementation (under 8kg: 100,000, over 8kg 200,000) once a day on days 1,2 and 8 (do not give if the child has received in the last 4 months). If current or recurrent diarrhoea More than 3 episodes in 6 months Give metronidazole 5 days for giardia treatment. Give zinc sulphate 10 days. Vaccinations If the child is not up-to-date with their vaccinations, they should be referred to the nearest clinic for the appropriate vaccinations. Mannapack Rice For moderate wasting in uder 5 year olds and severe stunting in under 2 year olds give a supply of Mannapack Rice as per the table below. Parents should be told to prepare the rice for the day in the morning and give to the child in 8 separate sittings. (Mannapack rice table) All these children need a medical review in 2-4 weeks. All parents need to be counselled that if the condition of the child deteriorates (e.g. diarrhea, vomiting, fever, increase in oedema), or if the child loses appetite, they should immediately take the child to nearest health facility. Failure to improve significantly should result in a referral to the nearest hospital or refeeding centre depending on the clinical presentation.

Severe Wasting Infants and children who are 6–59 months of age and have a mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm, have a z-score of -3 or less or who have any degree of bilateral oedema should be immediately referred to the nearest hospital. These children require broad spectrum antibiotics due to immunocompromised. Amoxicillin for 5 days as per weight should be started before transfer to hospital. Oral rehydration can be given with ORS if signs of moderate/severe dehydration, fluid balance can be difficult in children with severe malnutrition so proceed cautiously as to not fluid overload them reduce oral replacement by up to 50% depending on the child’s condition. We refer all cases as we do not have the infrastructure to give the close follow up required, there are good refeeding centres in the region (Nutre Hogar), often it is inappropriate to manage these cases in the community without support for the family. It can be very difficult to deal with cases where the family refuse to take the child to the hospital despite severe malnutrition. Usually this is due to mistrust of the local services and fear of leaving the community for a city far away. It should be made clear that Floating Doctors will support the family to travel to the hospital and if possible, attend hospital with them to help them navigate the health system and if needed support and advocate for them. If despite this, they refuse to take the child to the hospital we need to notify the health authorities urgently so they can assess the welfare of the child. Severe Stunting Theses cases should be given counselling, treatment and rice (as per moderate malnutrition) and referred directly to a paediatrician to rule out an underlying medical cause. Severe Underweight Check the WfH z-score. Is the child underweight because they are stunted or wasted or both? If severe wasted they need to be referred immediately. Otherwise, it may be appropriate to give counselling, treatment and Manna rice (as per moderate malnutrition) with a follow up in 1 month with the centro de salud.

Ask family if they are recieving Red de Opertundades and Senapan (food stamps).
If there is a family with stunted or malnurished children who are not receiving both benefits, you must take all the details and discuss with the Floating LMP.
We will liase with social services so that the family recieves the support they are entitled to.

Relatively common in the communities we visit. The most common symptoms of scabies, itching and a skin rash, are caused by sensitization (a type of “allergic” reaction) to the proteins and feces of the parasite. 

Severe itching (pruritus), especially at night, is the earliest and most common symptom of scabies. 

A pimple-like (papular) itchy (pruritic) “scabies rash” is also common. In this climate itching and rash may affect the whole body or be limited to common sites (between the fingers, wrist,elbow, armpit and penis). [1]

Scabies is an itchy rash caused by the parasitic mite Sarcoptes scabiei [2]. Risk Factors are overcrowding, poverty, poor nutritional status, poor hygiene, children, immunocompromised individuals and elderly [3]. The elderly, and immunocompromised individuals are at particular risk of the crusted variant (Norwegian Scabies). They tend to present with clinically atypical lesions and are often misdiagnosed, causing a delay in appropriate treatment and increased risk of a local epidemic.

The diagnosis is largely clinical. A magnifying lens may help in identification of burrows or even occasionally mites [4]. If in doubt the case can be posted with images on SERMO.

Skin scraping can be taken for evaluation under the microscope for definitive diagnosis.

Treat whole family, where possible, wash bedding, hammocks and clothes in very hot water and leave to try in direct sunlight. Soap and counselling on good hygiene. The primary method of treatment for scabies is by either oral anthelmintic (ivermectin), or topical application of a parasiticidal preparation (permethrin) overnight to the whole body from head to toe. Which agent to use is dependant on the weight of the patient, if the patient is pregnant or if the patient is breast feeding. Treatment is should be repeated a week later. If there is secondary bacterial infection present, this should be treated first with antibiotics for 24-48 hours in the case of permethrin to avoid systemic absorption. Under 15kg, Pregnant/Breastfeeding* Permethrin cream 5%** -Apply to body on day 1 and day 8. -Apply at night -Avoid face. -Mittens to avoid ingestion in infants. -Don't apply to broken/inflamed skin. -Treat bacterial infections first with for 24-48hrs. Do not apply after a hot bath; increases systemic absorption and removes the drug from its treatment site. *Ivermectin contraindicated in all three. **Children over 2 months. Over 15kg Ivermectin 200 mcg/kg once, day 1 and day 8. Crusted (Norwegian) Scabies -Ivermectin 200 mcg/Kg (if safe) AND -Permethrin 5% cream . -Patients are often immunocompromised. -Consider Malnutrition, HIV etc. May require two or three applications of permethrin on consecutive days to ensure that enough penetrates the hyperkeratotic areas to kill all the mites. [4,5]

Secondary bacterial infection. Cellulitis, impetigo and abscesses may be the result, and bacterial skin infection can further predispose to invasive infection and sepsis.

Scabies can cause flaring or reactivation of eczema or psoriasis. Those whose immunity is highly sensitive can present with extensive dermatitis or even erythroderma.

Scabies has social stigma and may cause psychological harm with persistent delusions of parasitosis, shame or guilt. [4,5,6].

Leishmaniasis is caused by a protozoan of the genus Leishmania [1]. The presentation of Leishmaniasis varies according to the species causing the infection and the region in the world where a person is infected. There are 3 main types of Leishmaniasis [2,3]: - Visceral (Kala-Azar). - Cutaneous. - Mucocutaneous. This section will focus on cutaneous Leishmaniasis since this is the type that is mainly present in Panama [2]. Lesions start mostly on exposed regions of the skin which are easily bitten by sandflies. The lesions start as erythematous patches that change to plaques and ulcers. Unless there is a secondary bacterial infection, the lesions are usually painless. Many patients have limited cutaneous lesions that self-cure within 6-18 months, leaving scarred tissue. Leishmania Viannia Panamensis in one of the species present in Panama. Any Leishmania species in the Viannia subgenus can cause Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis (MCL). Sometimes this occurs years after an initial cutaneous infection. Thankfully, MCL is not common in the region but patients presenting with nasal congestion or chronic upper airway symptoms may in fact have MCL. Check for nasal septum lesions and/or refer to ENT.

‘Scattered cases of cutaneous and mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis occur in rural areas in the entire country, but most cases are reported from western Panama (Bocas del Toro, Cocle, Colon, Chiriqui and Panama Provinces) and from the west-central areas [4].’ L. (v) Panamensis is responsible for the great majority of the cases, mostly in forested areas from west to east, including Bocas del Toro [5]. The two-toed sloth is the main reservoir [5,6].

In cases where Leishmaniasis is suspected, consult with a Lead Medical Provider.

The diagnosis and treatment of Leishmaniasis can be provided free of charge through MINSA. 

For the diagnosis of Cutaneous Leishmaniasis, parasitological testing is required [7].

Consider the following -Number. -Size. -Evolution and persistence of lesions. -Location of lesions (e.g. on the face). -Other features ie lymphangitis. Medical Treatment Treatment often occurs in the closest Centro de Salud, based on clinical diagnosis and usually without monitoring of kidney or liver function. Standard treatment in Panama is 20 days of IM Pentavalent Antimony, which can cause reno-hepatotoxicity. We treat any secondary infections in clinic and advice and support patients to seek treatment if there is a strong suspicion of leishmaniasis. It is advised that any case of Leishmaniasis from a species in the Viannia subgenus should receive systemic treatment, due to the future risk of conversion to MCL. [9]

The cutaneous form differs from the visceral variety and doesn’t transform to Visceral Leishmaniasis (except in rare cases of immunocompromise in HIV). In certain regions of Central and South America with the Vianna subgenus, 5% of the cutaneous form may develop into Mucocutaneous form (sometimes years after the initial infection), which typically affects the nasal mucosa and is destructive in nature. However, in our region of Panama this seems to be very rare, but we need to be vigilant. [10]. Other potential complications of Cutaneous Leishmaniasis include [10,11]: Bleeding, superimposed infections due to immunodeficiency and disfigurement.

“Cellulitis appears as a swollen, red area of skin that feels hot and tender. It can spread rapidly to other parts of the body. 

Cellulitis isn't usually spread from person to person.

Skin on lower legs is most commonly affected, though cellulitis can occur anywhere on your body or face.” [1]

“The most common causative organisms are Streptococcus or Staphylococcus spp. but they can be caused by a wide range of both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.” [2]

Infections can occur after injuries (small or large) or without a clear cause.

Complications are uncommon but may include: abscesses, gangrene, thrombophlebitis/lymphangitis, chronic leg oedema (a late complication which may predispose to further episodes of infection). Less common complications (occurring in less than 1%) include: necrotising fasciitis, osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, acute glomerulonephritis, endocarditis, septicaemia, streptococcal toxic shock syndrome. For skin abscess, see separate section. [5,6]

General measures include rest, elevation of any affected limbs, and analgesia. “Folliculitis is a common skin condition in which hair follicles become inflamed. It's usually caused by a bacterial or fungal infection. 

At first it may look like small red bumps or white-headed pimples around hair follicles; the tiny pockets from which each hair grows. 

The infection can spread and turn into non healing, crusty sores.

The condition isn't life-threatening, but it can be itchy, sore and embarrassing. Severe infections can cause permanent hair loss and scarring.” [1]

“Damaged follicles are at risk of infection. The most common causes of follicle damage are:

-Friction from shaving or tight clothing.
-Heat and sweat, (rubber gloves/waders).
-Skin conditions, such as dermatitis and acne.
-Injuries, such as scrapes or surgical wounds.
-Coverings: plastic dressings, adhesive tape” 

[2]
The diagnosis is based on history and examination findings.

General Measures Avoid precipitating factors such as inappropriate clothing. Use separate washing implements and towels from other members of the household. Pharmacological treatment Mild, superficial folliculitis may resolve with hygiene measures and without medical treatment. Treat deeper folliculitis as per cellulitis. [2, 3]

Impetigo is a very common superficial infection of the skin. It can be divided into non-bullous and bullous forms. The non-bullous types represent the majority of cases.

Non-bullous impetigo starts as tiny pustules or vesicles that evolve rapidly into crusted plaques that tend to be under 2 cm in diameter. 

It usually starts on the face or on the extremities where bites, scratches, burns or trauma have occurred. 

It spreads rapidly. Little or no surrounding erythema or oedema. Regional lymph nodes are often enlarged.

Bullous impetigo has a thin roof and tend to rupture spontaneously. They are usually on the face, trunk, extremities, buttocks, or perineal regions. More likely to occur on top of other disease like atopic eczema. [1]

Impetigo In the UK Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism, Streptococcus pyogenes is the other pathogen involved, and on occasions both organisms can be found together. In warmer climates Streptococcus pyogenes is more prevalent. Bullous impetigo Is nearly always caused by Staphylococcus aureus. [2]
The diagnosis is usually based on history and clinical examination findings.

General Advice [3,4,5,6] “Advise good hygiene measures to prevent spread: -Keep the affected area(s) clean and dry, -Wash hands after touching affected area(s), -Avoid sharing of towels and bathwater, -Avoid scratching the affected area, -Keep fingernails short and clean.” -Mittens for scratching children. Localised impetigo -Soap and water twice a day. -Triple antibiotic cream 3x/day; 3-5 days. *Bacitracin or fusidic acid should be used in infants as Neomycin is contraindicated. Complicated / Widespread / Severe Impetigo 25kg and over 1st line: Cloxacillin 500mg 4x/day, 5-7 days. Under 25 kg 1st line: Amoxicillin 5-7 days. 1-4 years 250 mg 3x/day. 5–11 years 500 mg 3x/day. *Review 48-72 hours, if not improving add in second line if very severe. 2nd line (all patients) Azithromycin 3 days. Over 6 months: 10 mg/kg once a day. (max/adult dose 500mg once a day).
Cellulitis, lymphangitis, lymphadenitis, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome may occur occasionally. [7]

“Dermatophytosis (tinea) infections are fungal infections caused by dermatophytes. They tend to grow outwards on skin, producing a ring-like pattern - hence the term 'ringworm'. They are very common here in Panama and affect different parts of the body.”

According to site:
    - Scalp - tinea capitis.
    - Feet - tinea pedis.
    - Hands - tinea manuum.
    - Nail - tinea unguium (or onychomycosis).
    - Beard area - tinea barbae.
    - Groin - tinea cruris.
    - Body / trunk / arms - tinea corporis.

[1]

Infection is limited to the dead layers of skin but encouraged by a damp and warm local environment like her in Panama. The infection can also be transmitted between people, from soil and from animals. [2]

Eczema and psoriasis are commonly confused with tinea. 

Pityriasis versicolor occurs over the trunk and candida occurs in the flexural surfaces at extremes of age, in the immunocompromised, those with diabetes or patients on antibiotics.

If in doubt, take a picture (with the patient’s consent) and post the case on SERMO. This opens up the clinical situation to a number of specialists. [3,4]

Tinea Corporis 1st line: -Clotrimazole 1% cream 2-3 times a day. -Continue for 1-2 weeks after resolution. *2nd line at next clinic if treatment failure. 2nd line: -Griseofulvin 4-6 weeks. -Under 12yrs: 10 mg/kg (max 500mg) 1x/day. -Over 12yrs and Adults: 500mg 1x/day. Tinea Capitis -Shave head if appropriate. -Clean with soap and water twice a day. -Examine family: ringworm is contagious. -Clotrimazole 1% cream 2-3x/day AND -Griseofulvin 4-6 weeks (dose as above). Tinea Pedis -Keep feet clean and dry as much as possible. -After each use of boots if used- -If Severe: Clotrimazole 1% cream 2x/day: 4-6 weeks. [5,6,7,8]

The main complication is secondary bacterial infection.

Hair loss is a complication of tinea capitis. 

Tinea capitis can develop into kerion (boggy deeper scalp infection). [9]

Patients' knowledge of wound care is generally poor in this area. Initially assess the wound and the need for closure. 

Assess [1,2,3] the mode of injury, time of injury, type of wound, location (proximity to major vessels and nerves), shape of the wound, depth and direction. 

Also check to for the presence of a potential foreign body and for underlying structural injury.

The next step is to achieve haemostasis [4]. This can be spontaneous but may require pressure or elevation. Do not use a tourniquet.[4,5]

Please be aware of the fact that often the patient will be in a lot of pain! Analgesia is sometimes needed. Use lidocaine up to 3 mg/kg. NB: a 1% solution contains 10 mg/mL. [4,5] Wound Closure The timing of wound closure will be based on your assessment of the wound [6,7]: Primary Closure: Immediate closure can be used for simple wounds under 12 hours old with opposable edges. Delayed Primary Closure: If there is high risk of infection. Give prophylactic antibiotics and close after a few days. This is something that can be done on a follow up. Secondary Closure: Allow the wound to close by itself if a bite (except on the face) or it has separated edges or infection. This may result in increased scarring. Type of Closure [6,7,8] If primary closure is decided upon, generally we have 3 options available: steristrips, tissue adhesives and/or sutures. Bear in mind that sutures will need to be removed. Often this can be problematic in our setting so if this option is chosen an appropriate removal plan is essential. Steristrips can be used for small wounds or to allow for drainage where needed. For small superficial lacerations, consider the use of tissue adhesives [12] if available. If sutures are used, advise regarding appropriate follow up. Teach patient or carer to remove sutures in a hygienic way if follow up is not possible. Ensure to consult with the LMP regarding follow up and management options. In some clinic locations there are health workers who are trained to remove sutures. Ensuring that these health workers follow up the wound care after we're gone can be useful.

Antibiotic cream is not advised for wound management, as it can slow healing. Suture Removal [2,4] -Face: 4 - 5 days -Neck: 7 days -Arms and back of hands: 7 days. -Scalp, chest, abdomen, back: 7-10 days. -Legs and top of feet: 10 days. -Palms, soles, fingers or toes: 12-14 days. -Overlying a joint: 12-14 days. Contaminated wounds Dirty wounds and dog bites are best left open initially IF adequate follow up is likely to be available. However, if not: -Clean area well (sterile water/saline). -Remove debris and Irrigate the wound. -Close the wound and start antibiotics. -Clindamycin 150-300 mg 3x/day: 5-7 days. Dressings [11] “The first layer in contact with the wound surface should be non-adherent - eg, a lightly lubricated gauze with interstices. Occlusive dressings can lead to maceration with retained fluid. The next layer should be absorbent material to attract any wound exudate. Finally, soft gauze rolls tape can be used to secure the initial materials in place. Dressings may not be necessary if the wound is dry and extra protection is not required.” [13,11]. Whilst rabies is relatively rare, there have been some cases reported in Panama [12]. Patients with bat bites need rabies postexposure immunisation. For all dirty wounds (e.g. animal bites or those involving metals), refer the patient to hospital for tetanus vaccination if the patient is not uptodate [13], the CDC recommends a booster every 10 years.

Counselling Explain clearly wound care highlighting the importance of: -Clean water/dressing. -Keeping wound dry. -Changing dressing if gets wet. -Daily review. -Counselling on poor healing/infection.

Pulmonary TB is the commonest initial presentation, however it may also be extra-pulmonary; tuberculosis meningitis, lymph node tuberculosis, spinal tuberculosis etc.

The possibility of TB should be considered in any person with risk factors for TB exposure, who has suggestive symptoms. These include:
-Chronic Fever.
-Malaise.
-Pleuritic chest pain.
-Cough longer than 15 days.
-Drenching Night sweats.
-Weight loss.
-Haemoptysis.
-Clubbing.
-Erythema nodosum.

Pulmonary tuberculosis is an airborne infection caused by mycobacterium tuberculosis. Primary infection heals spontaneously in immunocompetent patients in 90% of cases.

Tuberculosis has been on the rise in Panama [1-3]. In 2005, 1,565 cases were reported (48.5 per 100,000 population). The areas at greatest risk are the provinces of Kuna Yala (210 per 100,000 population), Ngöbe Buglé (152.6) and Bocas del Toro (107).

[1]

Always Ask -If HIV status is known. -Details of known TB contacts. -Any MDR TB contacts? (taking injectables?). -Previous TB treatment details.* *When, how long, tablets or injectables. Completed treatment? An individualised plan should be made based on the patient’s location and clinical picture. For Example: IF symptoms do not resolve with antibiotics then the patient needs to attend the local hospital. In cases where Tuberculosis is suspected, discuss with the Clinic Manager and Lead Medical Provider as soon as you have a suspicion. Depending on the location of the patient, they can be investigated (and subsequently treated) for tuberculosis free of charge through MINSA (Ministerio de Salud). Sometimes we support the patient with a referral to the nearest centre that can perform sputum testing and sometimes we transport the sputum ourselves.

Presumptive Pulmonary TB cases in Clinic -Cough for over 15 days without other cause. -Face masks given at earliest opportunity. -Patient separated from other clinic patients. -Staff to wear masks during consultation. -Consultations in well ventilated area. -Treat as bacterial pneumonia. -Give patient 2 empty sputum containers. -2 samples to be collected on follow up. Anti-Tuberculous medications are commenced by MINSA. Our role at Floating Doctors is to act alongside the responsible health authorities. Often patients can develop other chest symptoms alongside their tuberculosis (COPD/Fibrosis/Bronchiectasis/Aspergilloma). These must be addressed where appropriate and not simply brushed under the umbrella term ‘tuberculosis’.

Collecting Samples in Clinic -Label containers before giving to patient. -Label: Name, community, DOB, Cedula. -2 samples to be brought back to follow up. -Both morning samples taken 1 hr apart. -We need sputum not saliva. -Saliva only samples will be discarded. Gastrointestinal illnesses are very commonly seen in clinic, particularly acute gastroenteritis and gastrointestinal helminth infections. 

Ascariasis, ancylostomiasis and trichuriasis are some of the most common soil-transmitted helminths in Panama. 

A big part of trying to prevent the number and severity of infections is to give health education alongside the prescribed medications. 

Advise patients to wash their hands after using the latrine and before eating, boil their water if they have no clean water supply, peel fruit and vegetables, and cook their meat thoroughly.

We routinely give patients and their families one dose of Albendazole for helminths every 6 months. 

For children aged 1-2 years, a single 200mg tablet can be given, over 2 years 400mg. Albendazole should not be given to children under 6 months.

A single dose of albendazole can treat ascariasis, eosinophilic enterocolitis due to A. caninum, Trichostrongylosis, Hookworm (Necator or Ancylostoma).

For suspected cases of enterobius vermicularis (pinworm), i.e. if they see worms in their stool - advise patients to take another dose 2 weeks after the first one.
 
Although high priority should be accorded to the treatment of pregnant women, albendazole should not be administered during the first trimester. 

Give 400mg to women in the 2nd trimester and again in the 3rd trimester, as per WHO guidelines.

Adverse reactions: Transient gastrointestinal discomfort and headache have occasionally been reported. 

Always try to give the doses during clinic, so that we are present for any potential allergic reactions.

Diarrhoea is the abnormal passage of loose or liquid stools more than three times daily and/or a volume of stool greater than 200 g/day [1]. 

Acute diarrhea is usually defined as that lasting less than four weeks and chronic diarrhea as that lasting more than four weeks. 

There are 2 clinical types, diarrhoea with blood (dysentery) and without (60% caused by viruses).

Common viruses causing diarrhoea are rotavirus (offensive smell), norovirus (vomiting), adenovirus. 

Common bacterial causes (most not needed antibiotics, and may worsen the diarrhoea or lead to more complications), E Coli, Campylobacter, Salmonella.

Infectious Diarrhoea Eating raw, undercooked, unwashed, or improperly handled meat, poultry products, dairy products, fruits, vegetables, shellfish, and seafood. Drinking contaminated water or beverages. Inadvertently ingesting fecal matter, protozoa eggs, or viruses by touching the mouth with dirty or improperly washed hands. Helminths are multicellular parasites with complex life cycles within and outside of human hosts. 

Patients can present themselves with symptoms of bloating, non specific abdominal pain, persistent/intermittent diarrhoea +/- nausea or vomiting. However patients are often asymptomatic.

Whipworm (trichuriasis) specifically can cause loose stools containing mucus and/or blood, nocturnal stooling and rectal prolapse in the setting of heavy infection. 

Roundworm (ascariasis) is associated with transient respiratory problems in the beginning of infection. While the most common symptom of pinworm (enterobiasis) is perianal itching (predominantly at night).

Roundworm, hookworm and whipworm are some of the most common soil-transmitted helminths in Panama.

Autoinfection occurs by water, food or hands contaminated with soil. Person-to-person transmission can occur by eating food touched by contaminated hands or by handling contaminated cloths, bed linens or other environmental surfaces.

In addition, eggs (e.g. of pinworm) may become airborne, inhaled and swallowed. After ingestion eggs hatch and release larvae in the small intestine and the gastrointestinal tract and cause symptoms.

Hookworm is usually transmitted by larval penetration of the human skin. Therefore, preventative measures include wearing shoes.

[1, 2, 3,]
History -Diarrhoea. -Visualisation of worms in stool. -Rectal prolapse. -Vomiting worms. -Hygiene knowledge/practices. Examination -Abdominal palpation. -Nutritional status.

For persistent symptoms unresponsive to initial Albendazole treatment consider doing a stool examination. 

Eggs can be found when infected with i.e. roundworm and whipworm. 

The utility of stool examination is limited for pinworm since worms and eggs are not generally passed in the stool.

Certain infections can cause peripheral eosinophilia in blood examination.

Albendazole every 6 months. 6m-2yrs 200mg once. 2 yrs–Adults 400 mg once. Patients will often have seen worms in the stool, but not always. Give 2 doses, separated by 2 weeks if a large worm burden is suspected (e.g. worms seen in stool, vomiting worms, anaemia or stunted growth). In cases of anemia (with suspected hookworm infection); iron supplements can be given together with the treatment. Consider treatment of whole household due to high transmission rates. Amoebiasis is a parasitic infection due to intestinal protozoa, with faecal oral transmission. Generally it has a subacute onset, usually over one to three weeks. 

Symptoms range from mild diarrhea to severe dysentery producing abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and bloody stools. 

Rarely, it presents itself extra-intestinal; most commonly with an amoebic liver abscess.

Giardia is a protozoa causing Diarrhoea, upper GI gases, greasy stools, stomach or abdominal cramps, nausea/vomiting and dehydration (loss of fluids). In severe cases anaemia and weight loss can occur.
Faecal-oral transmission. Drinking infected food or water. Organisms Giardia. Amoeba.

The pathogenesis of urinary tract infection begins with colonization of the vaginal introitus by uropathogens from the fecal flora, followed by ascension via the urethra into the bladder.

The microbial spectrum of uncomplicated cystitis and pyelonephritis in women consists mainly of Escherichia coli (75 to 95 percent).

Occasionally, caused by other species of Enterobacteriaceae, such as Proteus mirabilis and Klebsiella pneumoniae, and other bacteria such as Staphylococcus saprophyticus

The main risk factors include recent sexual intercourse, recent spermicide use, and a history of urinary tract infection.

Urinary Tract Infections are common in our region due to chronic dehydration.

Urinalysis by urine dipstick. Asses for leukocyte esterase, nitrite and haematuria. Leukocytes and nitrates are most accurate for predicting a UTI. Haematuria is useful in ruling out urethritis or vaginitis. Caution A dipstick negative for both leukocyte esterase or nitrite cannot be reliably used to rule out infection if the history is strongly suggestive of urinary tract infection.

The clinical diagnosis is made in a presentation consistent with that of a urinary tract infection and is supported by urinalysis evidence. We have found that 1+ or 2+ leukocytes are not uncommon in our patients, usually due to dehydration. If possible ensure the patient is hydrated before giving a sample and it is a clean catch midstream sample urine (MSSU) to avoid contamination and false positive results. Occasionally, UTIs can present with haematuria also. Due to potential complications, we have a lower threshold of treatment for pregnant women (not requiring nitrites). UTI in Pregnant women Leukocytes 2+ If no nitrites repeat and treat if still 2+ leu. UTI in Men and Non-Pregnant Women Leukocytes 2+, Nitrites +. If no nitrites then unlikely UTI. Treat if nitrites -ve only if high suspicion. Examination -Abdominal palpation. -Palpation for renal angle tenderness.

Second line: Cefalexin 500mg 2x/day for 3 days. UTI in men and complicated UTI in women First line: Cefalexin 500mg 3x/day for 10-14 days. Second line: Ciprofloxacin 500mg 3x/day for 10-14 days. “The clinical decision as to whether an epileptic seizure has occurred should be based on the combination of the description of the attack and different symptoms. A detailed history from the patient and any witness is essential.” There are simple partial, complex partial and generalised seizures. Seizures can start as partial and progress to generalised. Tonic Clonic (Grand Mal) -Generalised seizure. -Patient becomes rigid. -Falls to floor. -Jerking movements of all 4 limbs. -Patient is unconscious and unresponsive. -May bite tongue or double incontinence. -Post ictal drowsiness - 30 minutes. Absence Seizure (Petit Mal) -Generalised Seizure. -Patient becomes absent. -Unresponsive. -Will not remember the episode. Partial Seizures -Can be simple (conscious) -Can be complex (impaired consciousness) -Can affect motor, sensory, psyche. [1]

There are numerous causes of seizures [2,3]. Seizures can be idiopathic (epilepsy), due to cerebrovascular disease, head injury, drug induced, due to metabolic disturbance amongst other factors.

A particular cause to think about in our setting is central nervous system infection. Panama is known to have relatively high rates of Neurocysticercosis [126–129] so consider this as a possibility.

Pseudoseizures should always be in the differential as they are not an uncommon presentation in any setting.

Whilst history is crucially important for the diagnosis of a cause of a seizure, it is equally as important that reversible causes are ruled out. As such referral to hospital where blood tests and imaging can be performed is crucial.

Identify any potential triggers for seizures and educate accordingly. Potential Triggers[2,3,4] -Sleep deprivation. -Medication non-adherence. -Alcohol (Excess or withdrawal). -Drugs. -Bright/Flashing lights. If a patient is already established on medications, switching over to other ones can be extremely problematic if not monitored adequately. As such this should only be done by a specialist in our setting. If you know a patient is on medication, we can re-supply it. Alternatively, Friday follow up can be utilised to acquire the necessary medication and then provide it to the patient. For decisions on whether or not to commence new medications, it is usually best to refer onto a specialist. This is because anti-epileptic drugs will often require close monitoring when first initiated [4,5]. Carbamazepine. Adult; Initially 400 mg daily in 1–2 divided doses, increased until symptoms controlled; usual dose 400–600 mg daily in 1–2 divided doses; maximum 1.6 g per day. Child 5–11 years; Initially 5 mg/kg daily in 1–2 divided doses, then increased in steps of 2.5–5 mg/kg every 3–7 days as required, dose should be increased slowly; maintenance 10–15 mg/kg daily in 1–2 divided doses, increased if necessary up to 20 mg/kg daily in 1–2 divided doses. Hypertension (HTN) is usually asymptomatic, except in accelerated hypertension.

All patients need a full history and physical examination. Look for a cause (renal, endocrine, etc, as above), particularly in the young, the severely hypertensive and those with resistant hypertension [1].

Everyone has high blood pressure from time to time. To make a diagnosis it is really important that a minimum of 3 high blood pressure readings are taken (at least 2 on separate visits) before starting someone on lifelong treatment with potential side effects.

[2]

Measure BP on at least 3 separate occasions: all readings need to be elevated for a diagnosis of hypertension. Repeat readings can be taken on follow up before treatment started. *If a patient has not had medications for a while and their BP is normal do not restart the medications. Essential Hypertension -Idiopathic (lifestyle/genetics/other). -Accounts for the majority of cases. -Particularly in the older patient. Secondary Hypertension -Renal disease (CKD/PCKD). -Endocrine conditions. -Pregnancy. Refer to hospital if you are suspecting secondary hypertension in a patient. Modifiable risk factors -Excess weight. -Excess dietary salt intake. -Lack of physical activity. -Excessive alcohol intake. -Stress. Non-modifiable risk factors -Older age. -Family history. -Ethnicity.* -Gender.** *HBP is the most common cardiovascular risk factor among Panamanians and consequently an important public health problem in Panama. **BP tends to be higher in men than in women up to the age of 65 years, whereas the opposite tends to be true over the age of 65 years. [3,4]

Routine Assessment -Screen for diabetes. -Risk factor assessment. -Lifestyle advice. -Aspirin secondary prevention if needed.* -Urine dipstick.** -Fundoscopy if visual problems.** -Review of medications*** -Ask about postural symptoms. -Mark for 3 months follow up. -Consider secondary causes (e.g. if young). *Use aspirin ONLY in patients with angina, previous MI, peripheral arterial disease, previous TIA/Stroke. NOT primary prevention. **To assess end organ damage ***Dose, side effects, problems and adherence. See Maternal Health section for Hypertension in pregnancy, Pregnancy induced hypertension and pre-eclampsia. [2, 3, 4]

Measure BP on at least 3 separate occasions (Minimum 2 different days); all readings need to be elevated. This is vital to minimise inappropriate diagnoses in patients with 'white-coat hypertension'. Repeat readings should be taken on follow up before treatment started. Non-Diabetic Patient Under 60: Systolic: Greater or equal to 140 mmHg OR Diastolic: Greater or equal to 90 mmHg. Over 60: Systolic: Greater or equal to 150 mmHg OR Diastolic: Greater or equal to 90 mmHg. Severe Systolic: Greater or equal to 180 mmHg OR Diastolic: Greater or equal to 110 mmHg. Diabetic Patient Systolic: Greater or equal to 140 mmHg OR Diastolic: Greater or equal to 80 mmHg. Diabetic with end organ damage Systolic: Greater or equal to 130 mmHg OR Diastolic: Greater or equal to 80 mmHg. Pregnancy induced Hypertension Systolic: Greater or equal to 140 mmHg OR Diastolic: Greater or equal to 90 mmHg.

Lifestyle advice before starting treatment, where appropriate. Counsel patients on the condition and importance of long term control and monitoring. Only start treatment if an ongoing supply of medication can be ensured. If uncontrolled hypertension or severe hypertension, refer for investigations to look for a cause. If a hypertensive patient has not had medications for a while and their BP is normal do not restart the medications. Essential Hypertension First Line: Amlodipine 5 mg once a day.* Increased to 10mg once a day maximum. *Amlodipine is a good choice in our setting as there is no need for monitoring of kidney function and it causes less postural hypotension particularly in the elderly. Second line: Enalapril 10 mg at night (less postural side effects). Increased to 20 mg once at night max. Patients should have a creatinine test at baseline, after starting an ACEi and annually. Use Enalapril first line in diabetes OR under 55 years (particularly if proteinuria). We do not use higher dosing in our setting. Contraindicated in pregnancy and breastfeeding. Third line: Atenolol 50mg once a day. If known CVD (angina/previous MI) then start with atenolol. Do not use higher doses as side effects increase greatly. [5, 6]

Urgent referral to hospital in case of malignant hypertensive crisis (systolic over 200 mm Hg, diastolic over 130 mm Hg) or severe hypertension with accompanied by end-organ damage such as encephalopathy, dissection, pulmonary oedema, nephropathy, eclampsia, papilloedema and/or angiopathic haemolytic anaemia.

In case of hypertensive urgency (systolic over 180 mmHg, over 120 mm Hg) without impending end-organ damage. Treatment should safely reduce BP over a few days. Given the setting we are in, admission to hospital should be considered.

If severe blood pressure is corrected to rapidly there is a risk of causing a hypoperfusion stroke.

Complications of chronic hypertension: stroke or TIA, dementia, left ventricular hypertrophy/ left ventricular strain, coronary heart disease, peripheral arterial disease, renal impairment or hypertensive retinopathy.

Congenital heart disease affects 8 per 1000 born infants. 

The most common lesion is a VSD.  

In developed countries neonates have a ‘newborn check’ shortly after birth and again at 6 weeks, which includes auscultation for murmurs. 

Since most of our patients give birth in community, this screening is usually missed. 

ALWAYS examine heart sounds in children Under 2 years; this may be the first time they have seen a doctor.

Rheumatic fever due to untreated streptococcal infections may lead to valvular disease in older children- more commonly >3 years of age.

History Symptoms in infants: sweating, poor feeding, recurrent infections, failure to thrive. Symptoms in older children: shortness of breath, decreased exercise tolerance, palpitations, chest pain. Do comprehensive birth and maternal history and family history. Examination Plot height and weight and check centiles. Measure BP and oxygen saturations. Signs of respiratory distress. Dysmorphic features: e.g. hypertelorism (wide set eyes), epicanthic folds, flat nasal bridge, abnormalities of the palate, absence of secondary sexual characteristics when they should be expected. The most common genetic syndrome is Down’s Syndrome. All babies/ children with Down’s syndrome require a paediatric echo even if they do not have a murmur. Full cardiovascular examination: pulses (always check femorals in babies), clubbing, surgical scars, murmurs, thrills, heaves, palpate liver. ECG/ Chest x-ray are NOT useful in the evaluation of paediatric murmurs.

Innocent Murmurs -Seen in older children (over 2 years). -Soft. -Systolic. -Localised. -Buzzing/ musical quality. -Vary with posture/ position. -Can be accentuated by hyperdynamic circulation during intercurrent illness. -No dysmorphic features. -Normal growth.

For children with a known diagnosis please refer to follow-up list for plan (to be updated after echo appointment in David).

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) are acute metabolic complications of diabetes mellitus that can occur in patients with both type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus. Timely diagnosis, comprehensive clinical and biochemical evaluation, and effective management is key to the successful resolution of DKA and HHS. Critical components of the hyperglycemic crises management include coordinating fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte replacement along with the continuous patient monitoring using available laboratory tools to predict the resolution of the hyperglycemic crisis.' They have the characteristic 'pear drop' breath smell (from the ketones). We cannot confirm DKA diagnosis but if a patient is unwell has a high blood sugar and urinary ketones +++ then have a low threshold to manage as DKA. Children often complain of abdominal pain. DKA usually occurs within hours of the precipitating factor. Mangagement: -The most import initial treatment is IV fluids.* -This will help increase urine output and help start to reverse the acidosis. -Give IV ceftriaxone if unwell. -Urgent transport to mainland hospital. -Consider IV insulin.** *Adults 1 Litre/Hour for 1-2 hours. Children: 10-20ml/kg/hour. Be cautious in patients with heart failure, frailty and malnutrition. **1)if available 2)the provider is competent in giving (0.05 Units/kg/hour). If the hospital is 1-2 hours or less away then IV fluids and transport will be sufficient. To make a diagnosis of Diabetes two separate high Blood Sugar levels (BSLs) (including one fasting BSL) OR one high reading in the presence of symptoms is necessary. Please ensure you are familiar with the different units used to measure BSL (mmol/L and mg/dL) to avoid diagnostic confusion. A conversion chart is available in clinic. Diabetes Random BSL 200mg/dL or more (11.1 mmol/L). Fasting BSL 126mg/dL or more (7.0 mmol/L). These patients should be given the same lifestyle advice as patients with Type 2 Diabetes to help delay the onset of diabetes. The same risk factors should be addressed also. The diagnosis of IGT is usually made with an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) after abnormally high BSL (but not meeting the criteria for Diabetes). Urinary incontinence can be divided into those with stress, urge and mixed incontinence. 

Stress urinary incontinence.

Usually small volumes of urine.

Leaks when heavy lifting, coughing or during intercourse.

Urge incontinence.

Experience strong urgent urges to empty the bladder.

Will likely have increased urinary frequency.
 
Leaks before manages to get to the toilet or on stimuli such as hearing running water.

Usually involve larger volumes of urine.

Patients with mixed incontinence have a combination of the above, but one type will predominate.

The aim of bladder training is to reduce the frequency of urination and increase the volume the bladder can hold.

Ascertain how often the patient is passing urine daily.
e.g 7x a day every 2 hours, then write a time table.
Increasing the intervals between urination by 15 min. 

Advise the patient that they need to stick to the schedule.
Holding if they have the urge to go sooner,
or still trying to empty the bladder even if the urge is not felt. 

If an urge to urinate is felt before the scheduled void, 
use pelvic floor exercises and deep relaxing breaths until the sensation passes.

The intervals between urination should be increased every week if the current schedule can be achieved.

Increase by 15 min intervals until there is 3-4 hours between each void.

Reassure patients that bladder training can be challenging and they will have good days and bad days but if they keep with the schedule the times between voids will gradually improve.

Have the patient demonstrate pelvic floor exercises during a vaginal examination to ensure they are activating the correct muscles. You should feel a muscular lifting and tightening around your fingers. Advice to patients: Sit or stand in a comfortable position. Imagine you are trying to stop yourself from passing wind at the same time as you are trying to stop passing urine and slowly squeeze and lift the muscles. A feeling of tightening in the lower abdomen is normal. Try to avoid pulling in your stomach, squeezing your legs together, tightening your buttocks or holding your breath. Tighten and release 15 times every morning and evening. Increase to 15 repetitions 3x daily on next review after demonstrating correct technique.

Prolapse is very common and for many women is asymptomatic. The most common symptom is a vaginal bulge but many women may not report this voluntarily. In women reporting lower back or abdominal discomfort enquire about symptoms of vaginal bulge, dragging sensation or fullness and urinary incontinence. Types Anterior Wall (Cystocele): When the bladder bulges into the front wall of the vagina. Posterior Wall (Rectocele): When the rectum bulges into the back wall of the vagina. Uterine prolapse: When the uterus hangs down into the vagina and may eventually protrude outside the body (Procidentia).

Examination Women should initially be examined supine but asked to bear down to reveal the full extent of the prolapse. If the patient reports bulge but none demonstrated, re-examine in a standing or squatting position. Simplified POP-Q staging Identify the hymenal remnant and assess where the leading edge of the prolapse is in relation to this fixed landmark at maximum protrusion (i.e. when bearing down or standing). (Prolapse staging table) The Most distal portion is Anterior, Central or Posterior

If a woman has any of these factors, she should be strongly counselled against home delivery however the decision ultimately lies with the women. This list is not exhaustive so if you have any concerns please discuss them with the Float LMP. Contraindications to home delivery -Grand Multiparity (5 deliveries or more). -Age under 14 years. -Transverse lie or Breech presentation. -Multiple gestations (twins or triplets). -Previous Post-Partum Haemorrhage. -Previous Caesarean section. -Significant co-existing medical conditions (inc diabetes, epilepsy, valvular heart disease). Whatever the desired delivery location, all women should have a plan of how they will transfer to a hospital either when labour starts or in an emergency. Points to discuss -Who will take them. -How will they get there. -How will they pay for transport. -Who will care for other children. A plan does not need to be made at clinic but it is important to raise these issues to encourage planning. Emphasise that it is much easier to plan now than during an emergency.
All women 41/40 weeks of pregnancy not showing signs of imminent labour should be referred to hospital for a plan to be made for induction of labour.

What kind of delivery did she have and where did it take place?

How does the patient feel about the delivery did it go as planned, if not why?

Where there any complications, what impact could these have for a future pregnancy or delivery?

Lochia, bleeding after delivery, can persist for 6 weeks. However it should be gradually reducing in quantity and changing from fresh blood through to brownish or pinkish red through to pinkish white. While clots can be normal in the first few days, if they are persistent or associated with heavy bleeding this may be a sign of infection, endometritis, or retained products of conception. A lochia pattern that is not gradually resolving, but is instead swinging from heavy to light can also indicate the same. If There is Concern Check Hb and treat anaemia as appropriate. If well and bleeding not heavy, give oral antibiotics. Metronidazole 500mg PO TDS and Cephalexin 500mg PO TDS for 7 days. If bleeding heavy, has significant lower abdominal pain or tenderness , is septic or symptoms don't respond to oral antibiotics refer to hospital for review and ultrasound to look for products of conception. BEWARE it is very difficult to distinguish between blood and products of conception on USS postpartum.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) are acute metabolic complications of diabetes mellitus that can occur in patients with both type 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus. 

Timely diagnosis, comprehensive clinical and biochemical evaluation, and effective management is key to the successful resolution of DKA and HHS. 

Critical components of the hyperglycemic crises management include coordinating fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte replacement along with the continuous patient monitoring using available laboratory tools to predict the resolution of the hyperglycemic crisis.'
Causes of DKA and HHS -Previously undiagnosed patients. -Poor medication adherence. -Infection/Sepsis. -Dehydration/vomiting. -Alcohol. -Trauma/surgery. -PE, MI, other stress.

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) -Raised Blood Sugar AND -Raised Ketones (Urinary++/serum) AND -Acidosis -More common in type 1 DM. Patients are usually unwell or comatosed. They have the characteristic 'pear drop' breath smell (from the ketones). We cannot confirm DKA diagnosis but if a patient is unwell has a high blood sugar and urinary ketones +++ then have a low threshold to manage as DKA. Children often complain of abdominal pain. DKA usually occurs within hours of the precipitating factor. Hyperglycaemic Hyperosmolar State (HHS). -Previously known as HONK. -Very high blood glucose. -Severe Dehydration. -More common in Type 2 DM.

Sepsis is defined as a “life threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection”. 

The progression includes: infection → bacteremia → sepsis → severe sepsis → septic shock → multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) → death. 

Early identification and appropriate management is essential for improved outcomes in septic patients. 

The main goal for management in our setting is rapid restoration of perfusion, early administration of antibiotics and urgent transport to the nearest secondary care facility.

ABCDE assessment.Do not forget Glucose Clinical presentation Hypotension (Systolic: Under 100mmHg or decrease by 40+ mmHg). Tachycardia (100+ beats/min). Tachypnea (RR over 20 breaths/min). Hyperglycemia (glucose over 140 mg/dL in the absence of diabetes). Signs & symptoms specific to an infectious source. Signs of end-organ perfusion (shock). Decreased cap refill, cyanosis, mottling. Altered mental status. Reduced urine output; absent bowel sounds. qSOFA score (2+ associated with poor outcome) -Respiratory rate over 22. -Systolic BP under 100 mmHg. -Altered mental status. *qSOFA - Quick Sepsis Related Organ Failure Assessment. A detailed history & physical examination is crucial to evaluate for a source of infection. A full systems review should be performed to look for infective signs and symptoms, multiple sources may be found.

Secure Airway Intubation/mechanical ventilation may be required if the patient has encephalopathy or decreased level of consciousness (GCS under 8).
