Continuously monitor pulse oximetry to achieve target 94-98% O2 saturation (unless known Severe COPD, 92% may be more appropriate to avoid type 2 respiratory failure). Establish IV Access At least 2 peripheral venous lines for fluids and antibiotics, (Minimum gauge - pink 20G, ideally green 18G).

Early fluid resuscitation is a priority in sepsis-induced hypoperfusion or septic shock, which may be manifested by low blood pressure, decreased cap refill, decreased urine output, and/or altered mental status. Aggressive IV fluids with normal saline should be given within the first 3 hours of presentation. Adults Initially with repeated fluid challenges of 500ml. 500ml of fluid is given stat and the patient is reassessed afterwards for improvement and for signs of fluid overload. Once the blood pressure and heart rate and urine output have improved, fluids can be given over 2-4 hours with regular monitoring. *In elderly patients, malnourished patients and patients with known heart/kidney disease you should be much more cautious and start with 250ml bolus fluid challenges. Children WHO guidelines recommend initial fluid resuscitation in paediatrics with severe hypotension: Under 12 months old: SBP under 50 mmHg 1-5 years old: SBP under 60 mmHg over 5 years old: SBP under 70 mmHg Over 2 years- Normal saline 20 mL/kg IV bolus (under 5 minutes). Malnourished children and children under 2 years - Normal Saline 10 ml/kg IV bolus (under 5 minutes). Continually reassess perfusion status and administer repeated boluses until perfusion has improved, blood pressure is acceptable, or signs of fluid overload develop (ie. pulmonary edema). Be wary of administering too much fluid in patients with history of chronic heart failure.

Up to 5 million snake bites annually with 94000 - 125000 deaths globally. Dry bites (a bite where no venom is injected) occur in between 25% - 50% of snake bites, other literature shows even higher numbers of >50%. The outcome of a venomous bite depends on snake species, amount of venom, location of the bite (head and neck are most dangerous), patient age/weight/fitness and time to receive medical attention. Snake bites are most common among people living in rural, resource-poor settings, who subsist on low-cost, non-mechanical farming and other field occupations. Agricultural workers, women and children are the groups most frequently bitten by snakes. Panama has the highest incidence of snake bites of Central America (2800 bites per year). This region has two main types of snakes Neurotoxic snakes in the region (coral snakes): neuromuscular blockage predominantly induced by post-synaptically acting low molecular mass neurotoxins which can lead to muscle paralysis. Proteolytic venom snakes (fer de lance, known locally as 'dos equis.' and the bushmaster being the two most common) which cause tissue damage at the bite site.

Symptoms: Depending  on the venom characteristics (neurotoxic, proteolytic etc.). 

Patient can have local effects like pain and tenderness, swelling, bleeding or blistering. Bleeding can be localized or diffuse. Some venoms can kill tissue around the site of the bite, and internal organs can be involved

Nervous systems effects: locally close to the bite area or affect nervous system directly (stopping breathing muscles). Initially victims may have vision problem, speaking and breathing problems and numbness close to or distant to the bite site.

Muscle death: necrosis or rhabdomyolysis.

Eyes: direct eye pain and damage with venom in eyes.

A rare complication in very swollen limbs is compartment syndrome.

First aid for snake bites Immediately move away from the area where the bite occurred. If the snake is still attached use a stick or tool to make it let go. Sea snake victims need to be moved to dry land to avoid drowning. Remove anything tight from around the bitten part of the body (e.g.: rings, anklets, bracelets) as these can cause harm if swelling occurs. Reassure the victim. Many snake bites are caused by non-venomous snakes. And even after most venomous snake bites the risk of death is not immediate. Immobilize the person completely. Splint the limb to keep it still. Use a makeshift stretcher to carry the person to a place where transport is available to take them to a health facility. Never use a tight arterial tourniquet. The Australian Pressure Immobilization Bandage (PIB) Method is only recommended for bites by neurotoxic snakes that do not cause local swelling. Applying pressure at the bite site with a pressure pad may be suitable in some cases. Avoid traditional first aid methods, herbal medicines and other unproven or unsafe forms of first aid. Transport the person to a hospital. Management before or during transport. At the time of a bite, the cornerstone of care is complete immobilization of the affected body part and prompt transfer to a medical facility. Tourniquets and cutting wounds can worsen the effects of the venom and should not be used as first aid. Additional measures include keeping bitten limb lower than heart, wound cleansing to decrease infection risk, supportive therapy such as airway support, and administration of tetanus vaccine upon discharge if the person has been adequately vaccinated against tetanus (WHO). Improving the clinical outcomes for the victims of snake bite needs much more than just access to safe antivenoms. Intravenous access should be achieved early, hydration state determined and corrected if needed, and vital signs must be closely monitored. Paracetamol may be given for local pain (which can be severe). Vomiting may occur, so place the person on their left side in the recovery position. Closely monitor airway and breathing and be ready to resuscitate if necessary. Contraindicated . Cutting into the bite site can damage underlying organs, increase the risk of infection, and sucking on the bite site does not result in venom removal. Do NOT use ice. Ice does not deactivate the venom and can cause frostbite. Do NOT use electric shocks. The shocks are not effective and could cause burns or electrical problems to the heart. Do NOT use alcohol. Alcohol may deaden the pain, but it also makes the local blood vessels bigger, which can increase venom absorption. Do NOT use tourniquets or constriction bands. These have not been proven effective, may cause increased tissue damage, and could cost the victim a limb. Extra note Antivenom can also cause serum sickness within 5-10 days of therapy. Serum sickness causes fevers, joint aches, itching, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue, but it is not life-threatening. In asymptomatic patients (bites without signs of envenomation and with normal coagulation), monitoring must continue for at least 12 hours , 24 hours preferred.

Formulation 800mg/160mg. Class Sulfonamide antibiotic. Indication Bacterial infections: Sepsis of unknown source – oral step down. Dosing 960mg three times a day, 7 days. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Renal failure. Can cause agranulocytosis.

Formulation 10mg. Class Muscle relaxant. Indication Acute, severe muscle spasms. Dosing 5mg Three times a day (maximum 10mg three times a day). Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Will cause drowsiness.

Formulation 10mg Class Antispasmodic/antimuscarinic Indications Bowel/bladder/biliary spasms. Dosing 20mg as needed upto 4 times a day for 3-5 days. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Antimuscarinic side effects, do not use if patient has glaucoma or bowel obstruction is a differential. Avoid in GORD and constipation.

Formulation 25mg. Class Antihistamine (drowsy). Allergic reactions. Insomnia. Dosage 25 – 50mg 3 times a day. 50mg 30 minutes before sleep. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Will cause drowsiness.
class Antihistamine (drowsy). Indication Allergic reactions in small children. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Will cause drowsiness.
Formulation 100mg. Class Stool softener. Indication Constipation. Dosing Children >11 years and adults: Up to 500mg/day in divided doses.

Formulation 100mg. Class Tetracycline antibiotic. Indications Bacterial infections. Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, Infective Exacerbations of COPD and Asthma, Lyme disease, acne. Dosing PID: 100mg twice a day for 14 days. IE COPD and Asthma: 200mg day 1, 100mg days 2-5. Lyme Disease: 100mg once a day for 10-14 days (28 days for Lyme arthritis). Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Children. Pregnancy. Causes photosensitivity.
Formulation 10mg. Class ACE inhibitor. Indications Hypertension. 10mg at night. Max dose in our context 20mg once a day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Acute Kidney Injury. Pregnancy.

Formulation 4mg. Class Glucose supplement. Indication Hypoglycaemic attacks. Dosing 10 – 12g glucose (2.5-3 tablets) to be given in response to hypoglycemia. Repeat after 10 – 15 minutes if necessary.
Formulation 200 mg (= 65 mg iron). Class Iron supplement or replacement. Indication Iron deficiency anaemia. Dosing 200mg 2-3 times per day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Constipation.

Formulation 150mg. Class Imidazole antifungal. Indications Fungal Infections. Dosing Vaginal candidiasis: 150mg once. Vulvovaginal candidiasis: 150mg/72hrs for 3 doses then 150mg weekly for 6 months. Oropharyngeal candidiasis: 50mg a day for 10 - 14 days. Esophageal candidiasis: 50-100mg 14 - 30 days. Tinea infections: 50mg once a day for 2 – 4 weeks. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Pregnancy. Hepatotoxicity. QT prolongation. Renal impairment.

Formulation 40mg. Class Loop diuretic. Indication Heart failure, conditions causing pulmonary and peripheral oedema (Heart Failure/renal failure/liver failure). Dosage Depending on clinical situation (Urine output/blood pressure) usually 20-40mg twice a day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Higher doses usually needed in renal failure. Hypotension. Can cause dehydration and acute renal injury.

Formulation 5mg. Class Sulfonylurea antidiabetic. Indication Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Dosage Initially 5mg daily, adjusted according to response, dose to be taken with or immediately after breakfast; max 15mg per day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Pregnancy. Renal impairment. Can cause hypoglycemia (usually dose dependant and very refractory – needs hospital treatment).

Formulation 125mg, 500mg Class Tubulin inhibiting antifungal. Indication Dermatophyte fungal infections with failed topical treatment. Dosage Children <12: 10mg/kg (max 500mg) once a day for 4-6 weeks. Children >11 and Adults: 500 mg daily, increased if necessary to 1 g daily, for severe infections; reduce dose when response occurs, daily dose may be taken once daily or in divided doses. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Avoid in pregnancy and breastfeeding. Contraception needed for a least 1 month after administration to women of childbearing age.

Formulation 100 mg/5 ml Class NSAID Indication Fever. Pain caused by inflammatory process. Dosage 1 - 2 months 5mg/kg every 8 hours. >2 months 5 – 10 mg/kg every 8 hours. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Do not give in febrile illnesses with rash (can cause severe reaction with chicken pox).

Formulation 200mg. Class NSAID Indication Pain caused by inflammatory process. Migraine. Dosage 200mg – 400mg 3 times a day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Only short term use! Renal failure. GERD. Elderly patients. Patients with Cardiovascular disease. Asthma/COPD .

Formulation 6mg. Class Anthelmintic. Indication Scabies, Head lice, Strongyloides infection. Dosage Scabies and head lice: 200mg/kg once day 1 and once day 7. Strongyloides: 200mg/kg for 3 days. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Avoid in children under 15Kg. Avoid in Pregnancy and breastfeeding.

Formulation 100mg Class Beta Blocker. Indication Hypertension in pregnancy preeclampsia. Dosage 100mg twice a day until obstetric review. If severe hypertension give 200mg single dose and transfer to hospital. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Peri. vascular disease. Asthma. Bradycardia. Hypotension.

Formulation 10mg. Class Antihistamine (non-drowsy) Indication Allergic reactions. Dosage Over 31kg: 10 mg 1x/day. 0ver 2 years, under 31kg: 5mg 1x/day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Drowsiness still may occur.

Formulation 1000mg Class Biguanide. Indication First line in Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Dosage 500mg 1x/day and increase to 1000mg 1x/day after a week. Then increase to 1000mg 2x/day after 3 months if poor control. Then increase to 850mg 3x/day after 3 month if still por control. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Do not use in satge IV/V renal failure (eGFR<30ml).

Formulation 5mg. Class Antiemetic Indication Nausea and vomiting. 2nd line in Hyperemesis Gravidarum Dosage 10mg 3 times a day as needed. only use for 5 days in pregnancy. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Avoid in children and the elderly (oculogyric crisis).
Formulation 50mg Class Beta-blocker. Indication Hypertension. Dosage 50mg once a day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Peri. vascular disease. Asthma. Bradycardia. Hypotension.

Formulation 250mg. Class Nitro-imidazole antibiotic and antiprotozoal. Indication Bacterial and protozoal infections: H. pylori. Amoebic dysentery. Infected skin ulcers. Formulation 10mg Modified Release Class Calcium Channel Blocker. Indication Pregnancy induced hypertension, Pre-eclampsia. Dosage 10mg once a day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Dizziness, headache, nausea, palpitations, peri. oedema, rash, tachycardia, vomiting.

Formulation 0.4mg. Class Nitrate. Indication Angina, acute treatment. Dosage One tablet under the tongue at the onset of angina. Repeat as needed. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Hypotension. Dizziness.

Formulation 100,000 IU/ml. Class Oral candida. Indication Dosage Adults and Children: 100 000 units 4 times a day usually for 7 days, Continued for 48 hours after lesions have resolved. Abdominal distress; angioedema; diarrhoea; face oedema; nausea; sensitisation; skin reactions; Stevens-Johnson syndrome; vomiting

Formulation 20mg. Class PPI. Indication Gastro-oesophageal Reflux Disease. Gastric protection when prescribing NSAIDs. Dosage Severe acute gastritis: 40mg once a day, For 3 - 5 days. Moderate chronic gastritis: 20mg once a day, for 4 weeks. Severe chronic gastritis: 40mg once a day, For 4 weeks. Gastritis with melaena: 40mg twice a day. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Increased risk of Salmonella, Campylobacter and c. difficile.
Formulation 4mg. Class Antiemetic. Indication Nausea and vomiting. Dosage 4mg 3 times a day as needed. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Constipation. Flushing. Headache.

Formulation 80mg Class Analgesic. Antipyretic. Indication Fever, Pain - children Dosage 10-15 mg/kg every 8-12 hrs. Maximum dose 30mg/kg/24hrs. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Liver damage and less frequently renal damage can occur following overdose.

Formulation 160 mg/5 ml. Class Analgesic. Antipyretic. Indication Fever, Pain - children Dosage 10-15 mg/kg every 8-12 hrs. Maximum dose 30mg/kg/24hrs. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Liver damage and less frequently renal damage can occur following overdose.

Formulation 120mg Class Analgesic. Antipyretic. Indication Fever, Pain - children Dosage 10-15 mg/kg every 8-12 hrs. Maximum dose 30mg/kg/24hrs. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Liver damage and less frequently renal damage can occur following overdose.

Formulation 5mg Class Corticosteroid. Indication Acute exacerbation asthma/COPD. Acute inflammatory arthritis. Severe allergic reactions. Dosage 30-40mg once a day. For 3-5 days. Formulation 25mg. Class Antihistamine (drowsy), Antiemetic. Indication Allergies. First line in Nausea and vomiting in pregnancy. Vertigo. Sedation. Dosage 25-50mg once a day until symptoms resolved. Formulation 500mg. Class Antifibrinolytic. Indication Heavy menstrual bleeding. Dosage 1g three times a day for first 4 days of menstrual period. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Patients receiving OCP - increased risk of thrombosis. Causes diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting commonly.

Formulation 2mg . Class Antimuscarinic. Indication Urge urinary incontinence second line. Dosage 2mg twice daily reduced to 1mg twice a day if not tolerated. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Constipation/Diarrhoea, dizziness, blurred vision, dry mouth, palpitations, tachycardia. Avoid if bowel obstruction, cardiac disease, arrhythmias.

Formulation 20mg. Indication Zinc supplementation. Acute diarrhoeal illness in children under 5 years. Chronic Diarrhoea. Malnutrition. Dosage <6 months 10mg once a day for 10 days. 6 months – 5 years 20mg once a day for 10 days.
Formulation 100mcg/dose. Class Short acting Beta agonist (SABA). Indication Asthma/COPD. Dosage 2 puffs as needed. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Tachycardia,Tremor (Dose related).

Formulation 2.5/3ml Class Short Acting Beta-agonist (SABA) Indication Acute exacerbation of Asthma, COPD. Dosage 5mg repeated as needed. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Tachycardia, tremor if taken excessively.

Formulation 1%. Class Topical pyrethrin. Indication Treatment of head lice. Dosage See directions on the bottle. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Safe in pregnancy and Breastfeeding.

Formulation 0.35%. Class Lubricating eye drops. Indication Pterygium, irritated eyes. Dosage 1 – 2 drops as needed for eye irritation.

Formulation 1%. Class Topical Sulfonamide. Indication Treatment and prophylaxis for infections of skin ulcers and burns. Dosage Apply once daily or on alternate days. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Systemic levels of sulfadiazine my approach therapeutic levels on large areas.
Formulation 10%. Class Emollient. Indication Diaper rash. Dosage Apply with every diaper change.

Antibiotic associated nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea. Increases risk of C. Difficile infection.

Formulation 250mg/vial (1ml). Class Cephalosporin antibiotic. Indication Severe bacterial infections including sepsis (Children). Treatment of Gonorrhoea (IM). Infant 15 days to 28 days. Formulation 5mg/ml. Class Corticosteroid. Indication Anaphylaxis, Severe allergic reactions ONLY where oral route is not possible, Asthma/COPD exacerbations ONLY where oral route not possible. Intra-articular injection (Adult) 0.3–3.3 mg, where appropriate, dose may be repeated after 3 months, according to response, Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Congestive heart failure; diabetes mellitus (including a family history of); diverticulitis; epilepsy; glaucoma (including a family history of or susceptibility to); history of steroid myopathy; history of tuberculosis or X-ray changes (frequent monitoring required); hypertension; hypothyroidism; infection (particularly untreated); myasthenia gravis; ocular herpes simplex (risk of corneal perforation); osteoporosis; peptic ulcer; psychiatric reactions; recent intestinal anastomosis; recent myocardial infarction (rupture reported); severe affective disorders (particularly if history of steroid-induced psychosis); should not be used long-term; thromboembolic disorders; ulcerative colitis
Formulation 50mg/ml. Class Antihistamine. Indication Severe allergic reactions. Dosage 25 – 50mg once. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Drowsiness.

Formulation 20mg/ml. Class Loop diuretic. Indication Acute treatment in pulmonary oedema. Dosage 40-80mg IV Stat dose, as needed. Higher doses in advanced CKD. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Hypotension. Dehydration. Renal failure.

Formulation 2% (20mg/ml). Class Local anaesthetic. Indication For local anaesthetic during minor surgical procedures. After third shock during advanced life support. Dosage 10-20 ml as needed, Subcutaneous use only. Cardiac arrest: IV. 1mg/kg once. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Bradycardia. Dizziness. Confusion. Hypotension (may lead to cardiac arrest).

Formulation 2%/10mg/ml. Class Local Anaesthetic with vasoconstriction. Indication Minor surgical procedures (not on digits/extremities) Dosage 10-20 ml as required, subcutaneous use only. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Do not use in digits/extremities. Bradycardia. Dizziness. Confusion. Hypotension (may lead to cardiac arrest).

Formulation 150mg/ml. Class Contraceptive. Indication 3 monthly contraception. Dosage 1ml every 10 weeks to 13 weeks and 6 days. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Pregnancy. Safe in breastfeeding. Can cause decrease bone density (particularly in <18 years).

Formulation 50mg/ml. Class Antihistamine (drowsy), Indication Antiemetic. Allergies. Nausea and vomiting. Vertigo. Dosage 25-50mg OD. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Antimuscarinic side effects (caution in glaucoma, prostate problems, elderly and young patients).

Formulation 5% in 250ml. Class IV fluid. Indication Hypoglycaemia with altered consciousness. Refractory hypoglycaemia. Dosage Give 250ml Stat for severe hypoglycaemia or refractory hypoglycaemia. Cautions, Side effects, Contraindications Hyperglycaemia if given to diabetes with normal blood sugar.

Formulation 0.9%. Class IV fluid (crystalloid). Indication Dehydration, hypovolaemia, sepsis. Dosage Adults: Initially fluid bolus of 500ml. Repeated as needed. Children: 20ml/kg Fluid bolus. Every single diagnosis and treatment must be given a code. The codes are written in the boxes to the right of where the diagnosis and treatment plans go.

There are multiple reasons why we require this information:
-Data analysis to plan for medication and equipment needs.
-Monitoring and Evaluation (impact of the organisation).
-Monitoring for any trends (e.g. disease outbreaks).
-Sharing data with local partners (Ministery of health).
-Application for public health grants.
